ComparePage.title: Compare
ComparePage.subtitle: Compare the caloric density of foods.
ComparePage.needTwoFoods: You need at least 2 food items to make a comparison.
ComparePage.goToRegister: Go to Register and add foods.
ComparePage.howWorksDesc: Comparison helps you understand caloric differences between foods, allowing for more conscious choices.
ComparePage.howWorksList1: Compare the caloric content of different foods
ComparePage.howWorksList3: Adjust quantities to match your portions
ComparePage.howWorksList4: Make informed decisions about your diet
ComparePage.exampleDesc: In this example, a banana has 71% more calories than an apple for the same weight.
ComparePage.tipText: When comparing foods, remember that calories aren't everything. Consider nutritional value, including protein, fiber, vitamins, and minerals. Foods with similar calorie counts can have very different nutritional profiles.
ComparePage.educationalIntro: Calorie comparison is a powerful tool for making more conscious food choices. Learn how to interpret results and apply them to your diet.
ComparePage.satietyDesc: Ability to promote feeling of fullness
ComparePage.snackExampleDesc: The apple provides fiber, vitamins and greater satiety with fewer calories.
ComparePage.proteinExampleDesc: Both are rich in protein, but chicken has less saturated fat.
ComparePage.compareTip1: Compare foods from the same category

siteDescription: Register foods, compare their caloric density, and calculate equivalence to make better dietary choices.
heroDescription: Register foods, compare their caloric density, and calculate equivalence to make better dietary choices.
featureRegisterDesc: Add food items with their name, calories, and reference amount.
featureCompareDesc: Select two foods and compare their caloric content based on quantity.
featureEquivalenceDesc: Find out how much of one food equals another in calories.
featureSaveDesc: Your food items are automatically saved for future use.
blogDesc: Access our blog with over 50 expert articles on calories, nutrition, and healthy eating.
eduDesc1: A calorie is a unit of energy. In nutrition, calories refer to the energy people get from the food and drink they consume, and the energy they use during physical activity.
eduWhyList2: Lose weight in a controlled manner
eduNeedsDesc: The average adult needs about 2,000-2,500 calories per day, but this varies based on age, gender, weight, height, and activity level.
foodTableNote: Note: Values are approximate and may vary based on specific varieties and preparation methods.
footerCopyright: © 2024 Food Calorie Calculator. All rights reserved.
footerDisclaimer: This tool is designed for educational purposes only. Always consult with a healthcare professional before making significant changes to your diet.

RegisterPage.title: Register Foods
RegisterPage.description: Add food items with their nutritional information to compare later.
RegisterPage.name: Food Name
RegisterPage.addFirst: Add your first food item to get started
tips: Use precise names like 'Grilled Chicken Breast' instead of just 'Chicken'
Check nutrition labels for accurate calorie counts
Register foods in their raw state when possible
Include cooking methods when they significantly change calories
RegisterPage.didYouKnow: The way you prepare food can significantly change its calorie content. For example, fried chicken has about twice the calories of grilled chicken.
RegisterPage.howToIntro: Accurate food registration is key for meaningful comparisons. Here's how to do it right:
precisionTips: Include brand names for packaged foods
Register homemade recipes as separate items
RegisterPage.fruitsVegDesc: Low in calories, high in nutrients. Watch for starchy vegetables.
RegisterPage.proteinsDesc: Includes meat, fish, eggs. Cooking methods greatly affect calories.
RegisterPage.carbsDesc: Includes grains, bread, pasta. Portion control is key.
RegisterPage.prepMistake: Fried vs grilled can double calories. Always note how food was prepared.
RegisterPage.genericMistake: 'Pizza' varies from 200-400 kcal per slice. Be specific about type and toppings.
RegisterPage.saucesMistake: Just 1 tbsp of mayonnaise adds 90 kcal. Don't overlook additions.
